ADDRS with D-dimer not fully validated and has its critics, but it‚Äôs the best I know of.

@MartinBromiley 8/n So, we‚Äôve raised awareness, got it on the radar, embedded ‚ÄúThink Aorta‚Äù into our team mindset. Everyone is looking for it everywhere. The seniors are going to be reasonably good at spotting the high risk ones and arranging CT. But what about all the ‚Äúlow risk but could be‚Äù?

@MartinBromiley 7/n So basically, more ED senior clinicians so that fewer patients leave ED without being at least discussed (and ideally reviewed) by a senior. This will help with ALL missed diagnoses, not just AD.

@MartinBromiley 6/n In terms of SOP: RCEM recommend consultant-level ‚Äúsign off‚Äù prior to discharge for all patients with chest pain. But most EDs still don‚Äôt have the consultant (or even ‚Äúsenior reg level‚Äù) numbers to deliver this. And dissection can present without chest pain‚Ä¶

@MartinBromiley 5/n So, to answer your question:
More training in med school and FY1 about aortic dissection - doesn‚Äôt need to be a big thing, a one hour lecture would do. Reinforced later in training. Posters, mention at ED induction, use the excellent resources already out there.
@MartinBromiley 4/n But given current UK position, getting to a point where we stop missing the fairly typical ones would still be a big improvement.
@MartinBromiley 3/n The third challenge is that a proportion of dissections present in such an atypical way that even if we get the first two sorted, they will still slip through the net.

@MartinBromiley 2/n The next biggest challenge is how to safely exclude ‚Äúlow likelihood‚Äù cases without having to do a CT angio on then all (as others have said, doing CT on all of them would cause more harm than benefit).

@MartinBromiley The biggest challenge I think is awareness and education, combined with UK model of EM still heavily reliant on rotating junior doctors to see and discharge majority of patients, often without senior input.
1/n

@DrDKilroy @ShaunLintern Back then (nearly 20 years ago) it was an easy decision to make - it was ‚Äúthe norm‚Äù. @DrDKilroy @ShaunLintern My grandmother died of sepsis from a UTI. Potentially reversible pathology. She was 94, had dementia and had been deteriorating dramatically in cognitive function and nutrition over the preceding 18 months. She died peacefully in her own bed. We made the right choice for her.

@DrDKilroy @ShaunLintern This is indeed a massive issue and one that has changed dramatically over last 20-30 years. It is so hard ethically and emotionally, but we really do need to reconsider the amount of healthcare intervention we subject our frail elderly to, so often with no benefit for them.

@RCEMACPForum @AcmeDR Even with Majors, keep a perspective that most of these patients have problems that have developed over a few days, and that they may have waited several hours for ambulance, so they can probably safely wait a bit longer. Eyeball them all and focus on the ones that worry you.

@RCEMACPForum @AcmeDR If you manage to hand it over in the same (messy) condition that you inherited it, you‚Äôve done ok.
As Anu says, focus on safety and accept that people who have come with genuinely minor stuff can safely wait. Look at the screen/eyeball for the hidden sickies in the queue.

@RCEMACPForum @AcmeDR As others have said elsewhere on the thread, I think it‚Äôs about resetting your expectations in terms of the queue. Night staffing levels are usually designed to handle the amount of patients coming in overnight, not to handle that plus catch up a 6hr wait from the evening.
